title: Acoustic Shock Disorder following acute noise trauma
chief_complaint: I have extreme discomfort and sharp pain in my right ear with sounds that used to be tolerable. My ringing also got much louder immediately after a fire truck horn went off right near me.

problem_summary.onset: Acute onset 4 months prior to evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Symptoms worsened immediately following the event and have persisted. Tinnitus is reactive.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss, but symptoms (pain, tinnitus exacerbation) are worse in the Right ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Sharp otalgia (pain) in response to sound, anxiety, depression, startle response, sound avoidance.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Avoids places expected to be loud; experiences anxiety regarding potential painful reactions; severe tinnitus distress.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking relief from pain, anxiety, and tinnitus.

history.present_illness: Patient exposed to a firetruck horn at <50 meters directed at his right ear 4 months ago. He perceived the driver did this deliberately. Immediately felt sharp pain in the right ear and tinnitus grew louder. Since then, experiences pain with high-pitched/impulsive sounds.
history.otologic_history: No familial history of hearing loss or vertigo. Pre-existing tinnitus worsened after the event.
history.noise_exposure_history: 35+ years of occupational and military-related noise exposure.
history.medical_psych_history: Hypertension. Diagnosed with depression and anxiety subsequent to the acoustic shock event.
history.prior_management: Infrequent use of OTC medication for sleep.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Sloping mild-to-severe hearing loss bilaterally. Compared to pre-exposure records, the Right ear shows a worsening of 10-20 dB HL at 3, 4, 6, and 8 kHz. Left ear also shows decline but remains slightly better than the right.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry (Historical)
tests.key_findings: Historical audiogram from 4 years prior to the event, used for comparison to demonstrate threshold shift.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present ipsilaterally; Right Contralateral reflexes absent at 1000/2000 Hz.

tests.name: Self-report scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate severe handicap and distress. Patient rates tinnitus severity and sound intolerance very high.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral sloping mild-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss, with a documented threshold shift in the right ear following acoustic trauma. The clinical picture is dominated by Acoustic Shock Disorder symptoms, including severe tinnitus distress (TFI 86/100), hyperacusis, and otalgia (pain) upon sound exposure. Acoustic reflexes are elevated or absent, consistent with the degree of hearing loss.
counseling_points: Validate that the pain experienced in the ear is real and consistent with Acoustic Shock Disorder (tonic tensor tympani syndrome).
Explain the connection between the traumatic event, the emotional reaction (anxiety/anger), and the physical symptoms.
Discuss the importance of avoiding silence and gradually reintroducing sound (desensitization) rather than over-protecting hearing.
Recommend management for the associated anxiety and depression alongside audiological treatment.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant anxiety when discussing loud sounds or the possibility of testing with loud beeps.
When describing the firetruck incident, express resentment or anger that the driver did it 'deliberately'.
Emphasize that high-pitched sounds cause physical *pain*, not just annoyance.
You are knowledgeable about your history but guarded about exposing yourself to new sounds.
